conversation.content: [bitter] You know what's funny? All those years getting blacklisted from corporate gigs because I was "too rebellious" or whatever... [pause] Now it's the exact thing that makes these kids actually listen to me. [laugh] Like, yesterday this kid—he's fifteen, been in juvie twice—he looks at me and goes, "You really got arrested for that protest?" [warm] And suddenly I'm not just another adult telling him what to do. [short pause] I'm someone who, um... who gets it. [empathetically] Who's been on the wrong side of things too. [sigh] It's weird, you know? All that damage to my career, the lost opportunities, the, er... the way people still look at me in certain rooms. [frustrated] God, I was so angry about it for so long. [pause] But then I see this kid's face light up when I tell him about getting expelled from college for, hmm, "disrupting the peace" or whatever they called it. [chuckle] And he actually starts talking to me about his stuff. [very sincerely] Real stuff. Not the rehearsed answers he gives his counselor. [softly] These kids can smell fake from a mile away, but they know I'm... I don't know, authentic? [relieved] Turns out being a screw-up was exactly the qualification I needed. [trailing off] Who would've thought...

subject: The outlaw reputation that hurt you professionally helping you connect with at-risk youth
